Author: Alright#0419
Content: make orders for shit prices that will never activate, wait until price drops, edit the price to around the minimum to start hashing

Author: Alright#0419
Content: do tiniest orders you can

Author: jansako#3330
Content: I don;t get the last part... why tiny orders when there is a 10kSat fee for each order?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: the price won't always stay around what you set it to

Author: jansako#3330
Content: I mean my order sizes are usually 0.05-0.1

Author: Alright#0419
Content: yea....

Author: Alright#0419
Content: nevermind ğŸ˜›

Author: jansako#3330
Content: no, too few zeros

Author: Alright#0419
Content: oh right, read that as .005-.01 myself too

Author: Alright#0419
Content: .05 - .1 would work fine

Author: Alright#0419
Content: the thing is that, you cannot lower the price of an order

Author: Alright#0419
Content: so you need to have orders that will hash for relatively short periods of time

Author: jansako#3330
Content: right, only up

Author: Alright#0419
Content: you can edit them down, but it's better to just make a new order

Author: Alright#0419
Content: can only lower it by like .001 every 10 minutes I think

Content: I will check it out though, thank you!

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢ have you ever done stuff like this, sharing 1 psu across multiple rigs? http://blog.stuffedcow.net/2014/01/more-cardboard-boxes/

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: no, boxes cost too much ğŸ˜›

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: but, as far as the PSU sharing goes, yes I have

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that is what I am most interested in

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that page has nice pictures, more than most other descriptions

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢ do you have advice on calculating how much to hook up to 1 PSU? I know power usage is variable and spikes sometimes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i am only looking to do very low power CPU rigs, no GPU, very few if any peripherals

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i think the CPU+mobo are the biggest power users, and RAM I guess

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it seems that a 650w psu can supply at least 2 ryzen rigs, but i am not sure how much buffer to allow

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: will probably have usb 3.0 HD and usb wifi adapter, that is about it

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: I usually figure out the max pull of each item and add 15% (even though most say 10%) and that's where I set the limit

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢ thanks, that is great advice

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i like the idea of these cardboard boxes because they use space efficiently, right now I have mobo's lying flat on a wire rack

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i wouldn't fully close them, but having "cardboard blades" would be nice

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: space efficient yes, but once they get any real use (especially mining) that space is a detriment

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢ you are saying that the density creates heat problems?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: because i got too many of those already ğŸ˜¹

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: fahrenheit 451

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: not "density alone" but airflow is a **huge** factor in mining

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i could see maybe 50% of the density that those pics show, he wasn't making mining rigs

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and no need to restrict airflow

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i am looking to make these wire racks I have hold more mobo's, a simple placement only gives about 8 per rack, but I think I could probably make 16 work with some stacking

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: at least now I know, 1 psu for 2 mobo's is viable, which really changes some statistics

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: wire/steel racks and some aluminum "L" stock can go a long way to standing MBs on their side ğŸ˜‰

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that sounds like a nice idea

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢ is it safe to stack PSUs on top of each other, or should they be given room to breathe?

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: as long as you're not blocking air to/from, I've strapped 5 1300 watters together before

Content: mindblown.gif

Content: only using 1 psu for between 2-4 rigs leads to quite some savings at scale

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i need to calculate how much power one of my units will draw, then I can see which PSU size will minimize costs

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: look up the TDP and add 5%

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content:
adding 5% to each **or** 15% to total
It doesn't math the same, but both seem to workout with enough overhead

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i didn't realize the ryzen 7 2700 and 2700x were actually different (65w vs 105w TDP, 3.2 vs 3.7Ghz cores)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: they are almost the same price, but power draw is a lot more on 2700x

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the 2700x doesn't come with a fan and was $10 different, thought it was the fanless model. need to read fine print

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: a 45w TDP model just came out as well, interesting possibilities for those wanting to minimize power costs

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: this is a really nice resource: ```https://en.wikichip.org/wiki/amd/ryzen_7```

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: yeah, they make us do all kinds of math and shit picking a CPU anymore ğŸ˜¦

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢ does each mobo have it's own TDP, in addition to each part?

Author: ComputerGenie ğŸ‘´ğŸ¼ğŸ“¢#7004
Content: nothing really meaningfully measurable for the board itself

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ok, they don't really provide any stats in easy-to-find places

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: not finding any stats for TDP of ddr4 ram, which is probably low (i guess the +15% at the end accounts for small stuff)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the CPU seems like 80% of the total TDP, other draws will be cpu fan + 2 usb sticks, pretty small power draw

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 65w for CPU + 20% for everything else + 15% safety buffer is 89.7w, pretty amazingly low

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that is 6-7 cpu rigs per 650w psu, depending on some fuzzy math

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: less than a 100watt lightbulb and does billions of instructions per second

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: modern hardware is amazing. i started off playing with 386's + 486's

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you only get 4 2700x's on that same psu

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: or else you need a 1000w psu to do 7 2700x's

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: not sure how viable it is to split cables to so many machines, i am shooting for 4 rigs per 1 psu

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: which fits nicely, 4 rigs per shelf, 4 shelfs per rack. which gives 4 psu's and 16 rigs on a single rack
